text:
MITIGATION MEASURES
Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by
integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans
and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction
targets—NAMA’s target to reduce GHG emissions by 7-20% from BAU by 2020 and
NDC’s target to reduce GHG emission by 20-25% from BAU by 2030.
prompted_docs:
MITIGATION MEASURES
Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by
integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans
and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction
targets—NAMA’s target to reduce GHG emissions by 7-20% from BAU by 2020 and
NDC’s target to reduce GHG emission by 20-25% from BAU by 2030.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's efforts to integrate climate change mitigation into its policies and plans, specifically mentioning targets for reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand has made efforts to uphold its commitment under the Convention by integrating climate change mitigation into its national and sectoral policies and plans and implementing mitigating measures in order to achieve the national GHG reduction targets..."

text:
Thailand submitted
the 2nd updated NDC, which aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions
by 30% from the BAU level by 2030.
prompted_docs:
Thailand submitted
the 2nd updated NDC, which aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions
by 30% from the BAU level by 2030.
responses:
[1] Environment: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's updated Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) related to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, which falls under environmental topics. 

Supporting quote: "Thailand submitted the 2nd updated NDC, which aligns with an ambitious pledge to reduce GHG emissions by 30% from the BAU level by 2030."

text:
The contribution level increases to 40%, subject
to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer, financial
resources, and capacity-building support.
prompted_docs:
The contribution level increases to 40%, subject
to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer, financial
resources, and capacity-building support.
responses:
[1] Technology: The document discusses access to technology development and transfer, which is directly related to the topic of technology. 

Supporting Quote: "subject to adequate and enhanced access to technology development and transfer..."

text:
Furthermore, Thailand will continue efforts to
meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions
by 2065.
Thailand implemented NAMA’s mitigation measures and successfully achieved a GHG
reduction of 56.54 MtCO2eq in 2020 from 10 mitigation measures in the energy and
transport sectors which is 15.40% lower than its BAU level.
prompted_docs:
Furthermore, Thailand will continue efforts to
meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions
by 2065.
Thailand implemented NAMA’s mitigation measures and successfully achieved a GHG
reduction of 56.54 MtCO2eq in 2020 from 10 mitigation measures in the energy and
transport sectors which is 15.40% lower than its BAU level.
responses:
[1] Environment: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's efforts towards carbon neutrality and GHG emissions reduction, which are directly related to environmental goals and policies. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand will continue efforts to meet the long-term goals of carbon neutrality by 2050 and net-zero GHG emissions by 2065." and "Thailand implemented NAMA’s mitigation measures and successfully achieved a GHG reduction of 56.54 MtCO2eq in 2020..."

text:
As NAMA ended in 2020,
Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the
energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors.
In addition, Thailand has also increasingly developed supporting measures and
voluntary actions to mitigate GHG reduction, such as the carbon market and carbon
label schemes.

Figure: Thailand’s GHG emission reduction from NAMA implementation 2013-2020

 THAILAND'S FOURTH NATIONAL COMMUNICATION
VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION
Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate
change impacts in the last 20 years (2000-2019) by Global Climate Risk Index 2021
(CRI), both in terms of human impacts (fatalities) and direct economic losses.
prompted_docs:
As NAMA ended in 2020,
Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the
energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors.
In addition, Thailand has also increasingly developed supporting measures and
voluntary actions to mitigate GHG reduction, such as the carbon market and carbon
label schemes.

Figure: Thailand’s GHG emission reduction from NAMA implementation 2013-2020

 THAILAND'S FOURTH NATIONAL COMMUNICATION
VULNERABILITY AND ADAPTATION
Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate
change impacts in the last 20 years (2000-2019) by Global Climate Risk Index 2021
(CRI), both in terms of human impacts (fatalities) and direct economic losses.
responses:
[1] Environment: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and its vulnerability to climate change impacts, which are directly related to environmental issues. 

Supporting Quotes: 
- "Thailand has transitioned toward NDC, which aims to reduce GHG emissions in the energy, transport, industrial process and product use, and waste management sectors."
- "Thailand, a developing country, is ranked 9th as the most affected country by climate change impacts in the last 20 years..."

text:
Thailand,
by ONEP and RU-CORE, has developed a database of geospatial risks from climate
change by assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors:
water management, agriculture and food security, tourism, public health, natural
resources management, and human settlement and security.
prompted_docs:
Thailand,
by ONEP and RU-CORE, has developed a database of geospatial risks from climate
change by assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors:
water management, agriculture and food security, tourism, public health, natural
resources management, and human settlement and security.
responses:
[1] Agriculture: The document discusses "agriculture and food security" as one of the significant sectors assessed for climate impacts and vulnerabilities. 

[1] Water Management: The document mentions "water management" as a significant sector affected by climate change.

[1] Public Health: The document includes "public health" as one of the sectors assessed for climate risks and vulnerabilities.

[1] Natural Resources Management: The document refers to "natural resources management" as a significant sector impacted by climate change.

[1] Human Settlement and Security: The document lists "human settlement and security" as one of the sectors evaluated for climate risks.

Reasoning: The document outlines a comprehensive assessment of various sectors affected by climate change, explicitly naming agriculture, water management, public health, natural resources management, and human settlement and security. Each of these sectors corresponds to the relevant topics in the hierarchy. 

Supporting Quotes: 
- "assessing climate impacts, risks, and vulnerabilities in 6 significant sectors: water management, agriculture and food security, tourism, public health, natural resources management, and human settlement and security."

text:
The risk and vulnerability
assessments for climate projection are based on the top-down approach using climate
scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models
(GCMs) and RCP models, which are derived from data in the SEACLID/CORDEX SEA
Phase II project.
prompted_docs:
The risk and vulnerability
assessments for climate projection are based on the top-down approach using climate
scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models
(GCMs) and RCP models, which are derived from data in the SEACLID/CORDEX SEA
Phase II project.
responses: [1] Climate: The document discusses risk and vulnerability assessments for climate projections, specifically mentioning climate scenarios and models used for these assessments ("...based on the top-down approach using climate scenarios generated through the most updated version of General Circulation Models (GCMs) and RCP models...").

text:
For all the 6 sectors, 3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and
flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors.
prompted_docs:
For all the 6 sectors, 3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and
flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors.
responses:
[1] Agriculture: Assignment  
The document discusses climate hazards such as heat, drought, and flooding, which are relevant to agricultural sectors. The mention of "drought" directly relates to agricultural impacts, as drought significantly affects crop yields and farming practices. 

Supporting quote: "3 types of climate hazards—heat, drought, and flooding—are considered together with socio-economic factors."

text:
The vulnerability
assessments show that climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time,
and areas.
prompted_docs:
The vulnerability
assessments show that climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time,
and areas.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses "climate impacts" and "vulnerability assessments," which are directly related to the topic of climate change. 

Supporting Quotes: "The vulnerability assessments show that climate impacts are not homogenous across hazard, type, time, and areas."

text:
Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different
climate hazards.
prompted_docs:
Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different
climate hazards.
responses:
[1] Agriculture: Assignment  
The document discusses the vulnerability of different sectors and regions in Thailand to climate hazards, which can impact agricultural practices and food security. The mention of "different sectors" implies a connection to agriculture, as agriculture is a significant sector affected by climate change. 

Supporting Quote: "Different sectors and different regions in Thailand are vulnerable to different climate hazards."

text:
In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also
vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions, particularly the aging population.

OTHER RELEVANT INFORMATION AND ACTIVITIES
Chapter 5 depicts other information and activities of climate actions that complement
and empower the implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures enabling
Thailand to achieve the objectives of the Convention.
prompted_docs:
In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also
vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions, particularly the aging population.

OTHER RELEVANT INFORMATION AND ACTIVITIES
Chapter 5 depicts other information and activities of climate actions that complement
and empower the implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures enabling
Thailand to achieve the objectives of the Convention.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: Assignment 

Assignment: The document discusses the impacts of climate change on Thailand, specifically mentioning the vulnerability to socio-economic conditions and the implementation of climate actions. 

Supporting Quotes: "In addition to the physical impacts of climate change, Thailand is also vulnerable to changes in socio-economic conditions..." and "Chapter 5 depicts other information and activities of climate actions that complement and empower the implementation of mitigation and adaptation measures..."

text:
The information and activities
include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation;
education, training, public awareness, public participation, and public access to climate
information; capacity building; and information sharing and networking.
prompted_docs:
The information and activities
include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation;
education, training, public awareness, public participation, and public access to climate
information; capacity building; and information sharing and networking.
responses:
[1] Climate: The document discusses various activities related to climate, such as technology development, research, education, and public awareness. 

Supporting Quotes: "The information and activities include technology development and transfer; research and systematic observation; education, training, public awareness..."

text:
First, Thailand
has established a mechanism for technology transfer and formulated a climate
technology database and roadmap indicating technologies that require further
development aligning with key sectors stated in Thailand's NDC and Thailand's NAP.
Significant technologies have been developed to reach carbon neutrality and net-zero
targets in the energy sector, such as technologies related to electric vehicles and
hydrogen fuel.
prompted_docs:
First, Thailand
has established a mechanism for technology transfer and formulated a climate
technology database and roadmap indicating technologies that require further
development aligning with key sectors stated in Thailand's NDC and Thailand's NAP.
Significant technologies have been developed to reach carbon neutrality and net-zero
targets in the energy sector, such as technologies related to electric vehicles and
hydrogen fuel.
responses:
[1] Agriculture: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's efforts in technology transfer and development related to climate technologies, particularly in the energy sector. While it does not explicitly mention agriculture, the context of climate technology and its alignment with national commitments (NDC and NAP) suggests a broader relevance to sustainable practices, which can include agricultural technologies. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand has established a mechanism for technology transfer and formulated a climate technology database and roadmap indicating technologies that require further development aligning with key sectors stated in Thailand's NDC and Thailand's NAP."

text:
Second, research and systematic observation have been conducted
in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic
domains.
prompted_docs:

in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic
domains.
responses:

Supporting Quotes: "research and systematic observation have been conducted in climate variable sectors: atmospheric, terrestrial (i.e., land and water), and oceanic domains."

text:
Third, Thailand has engaged in implementing capacity-building initiatives
as well as Actions for Climate Empowerment (ACE) under Article 6 of the UNFCCC,
which involves not only climate knowledge dissemination but also the environmental
rights of the public to participate and access climate information.
prompted_docs:
Third, Thailand has engaged in implementing capacity-building initiatives
as well as Actions for Climate Empowerment (ACE) under Article 6 of the UNFCCC,
which involves not only climate knowledge dissemination but also the environmental

text:
Finally, ONEP acts
as a primary entity for climate information sharing, and Thailand cooperates with
international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address
climate change issues.

 CONSTRAINTS, GAPS, NEEDS, AND SUPPORT RECEIVED
Thailand has received support from various international partners to facilitate
climate actions in mitigation, adaptation, and enabling environment, including
the preparation of Thailand's Fourth National Communication (NC4) and Third Biennial
Update Report (BUR3) to the UNFCCC.
prompted_docs:
Finally, ONEP acts
as a primary entity for climate information sharing, and Thailand cooperates with
international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address
climate change issues.

 CONSTRAINTS, GAPS, NEEDS, AND SUPPORT RECEIVED
Thailand has received support from various international partners to facilitate
climate actions in mitigation, adaptation, and enabling environment, including
the preparation of Thailand's Fourth National Communication (NC4) and Third Biennial
Update Report (BUR3) to the UNFCCC.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: The document discusses Thailand's cooperation with international communities to address climate change issues and mentions support received for climate actions, which directly relates to climate change initiatives. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand cooperates with international communities at bilateral, regional, and multilateral levels to address climate change issues." and "Thailand has received support from various international partners to facilitate climate actions in mitigation, adaptation, and enabling environment."

text:
From 2020-2022, Thailand has received support
from multilateral and bilateral partners for a total of 34 projects, entailing 18 mitigation
projects with a total amount of 31,438,771 USD, 10 adaptation projects with a total
amount of 48,667,056 USD, and 6 enabling environment projects with a total amount
of 3,419,548 USD.
prompted_docs:
From 2020-2022, Thailand has received support
from multilateral and bilateral partners for a total of 34 projects, entailing 18 mitigation
projects with a total amount of 31,438,771 USD, 10 adaptation projects with a total
amount of 48,667,056 USD, and 6 enabling environment projects with a total amount
of 3,419,548 USD.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses support for various projects in Thailand related to mitigation and adaptation, which are key components of climate change initiatives. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand has received support from multilateral and bilateral partners for a total of 34 projects, entailing 18 mitigation projects... 10 adaptation projects..."

text:
Most support was a combination of technical support and capacity
building.
However, considering remaining constraints and gaps, Thailand still needs international
support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity
building to ensure the achievement of LT-LEDS in a short-term period (2025-2035), a
mid-term period (2040-2050), and a long-term period (2050-2065).
prompted_docs:
Most support was a combination of technical support and capacity
building.
However, considering remaining constraints and gaps, Thailand still needs international
support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity
building to ensure the achievement of LT-LEDS in a short-term period (2025-2035), a
mid-term period (2040-2050), and a long-term period (2050-2065).
responses:
[1] Agriculture: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses the need for international support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity building, which are often critical components in agricultural development and sustainability efforts. The mention of LT-LEDS (Long-Term Low Emission Development Strategies) suggests a focus on sustainable practices that can be linked to agricultural initiatives. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand still needs international support in terms of finance, technical expertise, technology transfer, and capacity building..."

text:
More support is
needed, particularly for technology development and transfer, which is essential for
mitigation and adaptation implementation.

text:
For mitigation, Thailand needs support
for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy
technologies (such as solar and wind), enhancing the potential use of Carbon Capture
Storage (CCS) & Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies, and
developing other technologies to achieve GHG emission reduction and a net-zero
emission.
prompted_docs:
For mitigation, Thailand needs support
for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy
technologies (such as solar and wind), enhancing the potential use of Carbon Capture
Storage (CCS) & Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies, and
developing other technologies to achieve GHG emission reduction and a net-zero
emission.
responses:
[1] Energy: Assignment 

Reasoning: The document discusses Thailand's need for support in transitioning to renewable energy sources and mentions specific technologies related to energy and greenhouse gas emission reduction. 

Supporting Quotes: "Thailand needs support for the energy transition toward renewable sources focusing on renewable energy technologies (such as solar and wind), enhancing the potential use of Carbon Capture Storage (CCS) & Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) technologies..."

text:
For adaptation, support is needed for developing a data map showing areas at
risk of climate change impacts and accessible viable adaptive technology.

risk of climate change impacts and accessible viable adaptive technology.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: The document discusses the need for support in developing a data map for areas at risk of climate change impacts, indicating a focus on climate change adaptation strategies. 

Supporting quote: "For adaptation, support is needed for developing a data map showing areas at risk of climate change impacts..."

text:
To enhance
the enabling environment, Thailand requires support for developing and strengthening
mechanisms, instruments, and policy implementation, such as financial instruments
and incentives to engage private sectors in green investment and capacity building for
all stakeholders to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans.
prompted_docs:
To enhance

and incentives to engage private sectors in green investment and capacity building for
all stakeholders to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans.
responses:
[1] Climate Change: The document discusses the need for mechanisms and instruments to support climate actions, indicating a focus on climate-related policies and practices. 

Supporting Quote: "Thailand requires support for developing and strengthening mechanisms, instruments, and policy implementation... to integrate climate actions into their respective practice and plans."

text:

demand functions using the regression software Microfit2.

responses: [1] Energy: The document discusses generating energy demand functions, which is directly related to energy topics. The mention of "energy demand functions" indicates a focus on energy economics.

text:
The energy demand
functions generated then is used to estimate the final energy demand and supply
projections and GHG emissions for the energy sector.
3.3.2 Summary of GHG Emission Projection Results
The projection indicates that the total emissions without LULUCF for Malaysia would
be 481,363 Gg CO2 eq for the WOM case by 2030 (Figure 3.1 and Table 3.5).
Continued implementation of the planned activities under the WEM scenario would
bring the emissions down to 367,603 Gg CO2 eq.
